items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 18:45 on 29/11/22 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 115 cubic metres per second and is falling slowly. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast.  We continue to monitor the situation.  Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message: River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. The next 48 hours will generally remain dry. Further periods of heavy rainfall are expected on Friday 2 December. We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

The River Adur is high but slowly falling following Sunday's rain. Minor flooding affecting gardens, rural roads and fields near Mock Bridge will reduce further during Tuesday and Wednesday. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The River Adur will continue to fall all week, returning nearer to normal by Thursday. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall, so please remain prepared for flood risk to return this winter. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

The water level in the Eastern Yar continues to broadly fall. At Alverstone, the river is falling at a rate of 1cm per hour. At Sandown, the river is falling at a rate of 1cm every two hours. Minor flood impacts affecting roads (including Golf Links Road, and Moreton Common Road), cycle tracks, footpaths and gardens will continue throughout the Yar Valley until tomorrow (30/11/2022). Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while the river remains higher than normal. As high pressure builds, the weather is now fairly dry for the remainder of the week. This will give the river plenty of chance to recover. Water levels are likely to return to normal by the end of the week. The river will remain sensitive to future rainfall, so please remain prepared for further flood risk this winter. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

The River Ouse is high in Barcombe, but slowly falling, following Sunday's rain. Minor flooding affecting fields, rural roads and gardens will reduce further on Tuesday and Wednesday. Please take care if using Barcombe Mills Road, Sharpsbridge or Fletching Mill Bridge, as these may still be affected by some flood water. Between Ardingly and Sloop Lane, the River Ouse has already fallen significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The River Ouse will continue to slowly fall all week, returning nearer to normal by Friday. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall, so please remain prepared for flood risk to return this winter. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers through Hellingly and Alfriston have fallen significantly from their peaks. Minor flooding affecting fields, rural roads and gardens will reduce further Tuesday (29/11/2022) and Wednesday (30/11/2022). Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers will continue to slowly fall all week. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall, so please remain prepared for flood risk to return this winter. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days from today, 29/11/2022.
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and remain aware of your local situation.

The Western Rother is high at Fittleworth, but now slowly falling following Sunday's rain. Minor flooding affecting fields, rural roads and gardens in Fittleworth will reduce further during Tuesday and Wednesday. However, water levels will remain higher than normal until next week. In Liss, Sheet, Iping and Midhurst, the Western Rother has already fallen significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The Western Rother will slowly fall all week. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall, so please remain prepared for flood risk to return this winter. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

River levels in Crowhurst have fallen significantly from their peak. In Bulverhythe, water levels will rise by about 30cm over each high tide, but the overall trend in Bulverhythe is also of falling water levels. Flood water will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe all week. In Crowhurst, only minimal flood impacts should remain, affecting, gardens, Crowhurst Recreation Ground and rural roads. This minor flooding will reduce further Tuesday (29/11/2022) and Wednesday (30/11/2022). Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The rivers of the Combe Haven will slowly fall in all communities all week. However, in Bulverhythe, river levels will still remain higher than normal. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall, so please remain prepared for flood risk to return this winter. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

Tide levels on early Tuesday morning at 03:00 (29/11/2022) are forecast to be lower than those experienced Monday afternoon at Climping. Only minimal flood impacts are expected. There may still be some minor pooling at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane, but expect this to reduce over the next few days.  Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 03:00 Tuesday morning (29/11/2022) will be 5.66 metres Chart Datum (2.61 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Tides will gradually reduce as the week continues. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

The River Arun is high but slowly falling, following Sunday's rain. Nearer Pulborough, minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens, but will reduce through Tuesday (29/11/2022) and Wednesday (30/11/2022). Between Horsham and Wanford, river levels have already fallen significantly from their peak. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The River Arun will continue to slowly fall all week. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall, so please remain prepared for flood risk to return this winter. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high, but currently falling, following an extremely wet November. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, the car park at Tesco and Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Only minor flood impacts are expected in Barnham. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes should slowly fall all week. However, through Shripney and Bersted minor flood impacts will still continue all week. It will likely take a fortnight of dry weather for river levels to return nearer to normal. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We continue to routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 30/11/2022.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Great Somerford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the past few days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge.   
  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Tuesday, 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.04 m and is currently rising by 40 mm an hour. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.24 m and is slowly falling by 5 mm an hour. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m. We are continuing to pump at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station.
Dry weather is forecast from today, Tuesday 29/11/22, and on to Friday this week. This flood alert remains in force due to water on the moors but with the dry weather, the situation will improve.  
We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are busy clearing weed screens and checking the condition of the spillways. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 30/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Stilebridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and remain aware of your local situation.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.32 m and is stable. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45 m, but this is unlikely with the continuing dry weather. 
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.78 m and is falling by approximately 10 mm per hour. We are currently pumping at Currymoor to reduce the drain level as quickly as possible to allow Cutts Road to reopen.  
Dry weather is forecast from today, Tuesday 29/11/22, and on to Friday this week. This flood alert remains in force due to water on the moors but with the dry weather, the situation will improve.  
We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are busy clearing weed screens and checking the condition of the spillways. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 30/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the middle to lower part of the River Cherwell as a result of persistent rainfall last week. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain out of banks especially in the areas around Thrupp. There is no rain forecast for today, Tuesday. We expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Glyme particularly around Woodstock. This is as a result of persistent rainfall last week. Water may remain on roads and farmland however further flooding is not expected for the next 24 hours. There is no rain forecast for today, Tuesday. We expect river levels to remain high on the river Glyme over the next few days.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Ray as a result of persistent rainfall last week. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain out of banks especially in the areas around Islip however they have begun to drop. There is no rain forecast for today, Tuesday.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday, or as the situation changes.

Tide levels on early Tuesday morning at 03:00 (29/11/2022) are forecast to be lower than those experienced Monday afternoon at Climping. Only minimal flood impacts are expected. There may still be some minor pooling at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane, but expect this to reduce over the next few days.  Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 03:00 Tuesday morning (29/11/2022) will be 5.66 metres Chart Datum (2.61 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Tides will gradually reduce as the week continues. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

River levels are high but steady the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 10am on 30/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to remain high at the Briantspuddle river gauge on the River Piddle as a result of the heavy rainfall over the weekend.  River levels are starting to fall but still pose a flood risk between Alton Pancras and Wareham.  We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out checking defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.  Please refer to the local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on Friday, 02/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Leach as a result of a period of sustained rainfall over the past few weeks. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain high especially in the areas around Lechlade.  There is no rain forecast for today, Tuesday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been high on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rainfall over the past few weeks. Therefore, flooding of low laying land is possible, specifically between Sandford Lock and Abingdon Lock. There is no rain forecast for today, Tuesday. River levels are not expected to get higher than they currently are but are expected to remain high for the next few days.
We are monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been operating weirs to reduce flood risk. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Stour area from Fordwich to Stonar Cut
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
The spring tides are reducing and when combined with river levels from the Stour the next high tide is not expected to result in flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. The next high tide at Grove Ferry is expected to reach 2.2 metres above Ordnance Datum at 5pm, 29/11/2022.
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and remain aware of your local situation.
